communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged beforehand. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are Intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamer leaves Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid fall fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 per cent, on returning within 12 months.
In addition to the above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnight of 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST.

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi at 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice every Wednesday at about S.S. a.m. in time for the Express to Switzerland, Paris, and London, leaving Venice at 2 p.m. and 11.20 p.m. Arrival at Trieste every Wednesday at about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reaching London every Friday 4.50 p.m. Passengers from Cairo will find special through carriages and Luggage-Van attached every Saturday to the Express Train leaving Cairo at 9.30 a.m. and will be conveyed directly to the Quay alongside the steamer.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: The Municipal election have come and gone without exciting much more interest than usual. Small though the number of electors is once more a considerable number of them have not taken the trouble to record their votes, and until the inhabitants take a greater interest in their own affairs, it shoald not astonish them that the result of Municipal labours is not much to their liking. For some years past, after each election, we have tried to flatter ourselves that changes have been made for the better, and that the result will soon be apparent. We freely confess that we have usually been disappointed, and not long since the cab strike, with its attendant discomforts, gave evidence of some friction in the Municipal machine, something similar to that which causes our tramcars to make the hideous noise they do. This cab strike was brought about by the heavy hand of our Municipal Councillors in the matter of taxation. It appears to us that they do not take any trouble to fairly differentiate their taxes. For instance, if P.T. 60 is a fair tax on a carriage with four iron-bound wheels and a number, why should that same carriage have to pay P.T. 150 if its number is taken off. and its wear and tear of municipal roads is much reduced by the addition of rubber tyres? It is true perhaps that in the present state of our roads a little more wear and tear is not of much consequence, still it might be taken into consideration. Again, why should the light one-horse numberless carriage pay the same rate as the much heavier two-horse carriage? This is not so in other countries. It seems to be one of the paradoxical conditions of Egypt that the less a carriage wears the road the more it should pay. It is only too evident that the numberless carriage is not generally an article "de luxe" and can hardly be expected to pay extra on that score. The mention of rubber tyres naturally reminds us of meter cars, and although these do not wear the roads much we hear that they are to pay the not inconsiderable tax of L.E. 5 a year, whether big or small, so long as they have four wheels. We cannot imagine any logical reason why the modest voiturette of 4 or 5 horse power, going only at a moderate speed, should be expected to pay as much as the ponderos, 30 or 40 horse-power machine going at about 30 or 40 kilmetres an hour and covering everything and everybody with dust. We reserve further details for a future occasion, at present we only wish to show that if taxes are to be increased this should be done in a more equitable manner.

To return to our re-constituted Municipality which will shortly begin its labours for the general welfare of our town, we again venture to hope that changes have been made for the better. We know that some of the newly-elected members are good men. We hope they all are, and that they may use their indience in the right way. The Municipality has much work ready to its hand, and for the moment nothing more important than the allotment and disposal of the largo area of land reclaimed by the new quay. The future appearance of the important sea frontage of the town depends largely on the way in which this is done. Now is the time for our Municipality to decide as to what restrictions they will place on buildings intended to occupy so important position in the town; if this occasion is lost, he effect might be deplorable for all time. Not only should due care be given to appearance, but what is equally important is that the land should, in preferance, be sold to those who really intend to build on it at once, or within a reasonable time. If this land is allowed to be bought up by speculators, with a view to waiting until they can sell it again at some abnormal profit, we may then give up all hope of ever seeing a proper sea frontage in our time. If this land is well laid out and wisely disposed of, the Municipal Councillors who may have influenced this work will have merited the thanks of their fellow-citizens.

div.head: THE UPPER NILE.
div.p: Not for the first or the second time, says the "Globe," the Congo State Government is seeking to establish a permanent military post on the Upper Nile. It has no right whatever to occupy a single inch of territory adjacent to the great river, the whole area being vested in England and Egypt jointly. Now, however, that a Little England Government is in being at Downing-street, it will be more difficult than ever to fence off the Nile Valley from Congolese incarsions. The Sudan Government, after forcibly remonstrating against the occupation of Inyelo by a Congolese armed party, has resorted to the stoppage of Belgian supplies via the river. So far, however, this boycott has not had any remedial effect ; the foreign force still holds on at Inyelo, and as it is said to be adequately victualled, arrangements most have been made beforehand for the dispatch of food supplies and ammunition from the Congo State. In short, all indications point to a deliberate design in this wholly unjustifiable trespass, and there seems every likelihood that force will have to be employed to get rid of the intruders. The entire Nile Valley, from the lakes to the Mediterranean, must in any case be kept free from foreign intrusion, that some sort of an "imperium in imperio" should gradually grow up above Khartoum. We have always considered it was a grave mistake to have leased a small area near Lado to Belgium.

div.head: EXPERIMENTS WITH EGYPTIAN COTTON.
div.p: The "Bulletin" of the Imperial Institute contains a report on some specimens of cotton from the Malay states. The specimens were from Egyptian cottonseed sown in 1903, and the sample was slightly inferior to standard grown Egyptian cotton in colour, fineness, and softness, but was of good length, varying from 1.2in. to l.5in. Commercial experts valued it at about 5d, per lb. Experiments are being continued in order to find the type of cotton most likely to withstand the local conditions, but there are obstacles to any great development of cotton in the Malay States, such as the difficulty of obtaining labour. It is regarded as practically certain that the industry would never repay European supervision, and indeed the Resident General thinks there is little prospect of an established cotton industry at all.
"A good article recommends itself."

div.head: New Sudan Line.
div.p: The inauguration of the El-Koreima railway line will take place on Thursday.

div.head: Shepheard's Fete.
div.p: Shepheard's annual garden fete de nuit has been postponed to Friday, 16th inst.

div.head: Khartoum Exhibition.
div.p: The inauguration of the annual exhibition at Khartoum will take place on the 23rd inst.

div.head: Egypt at St. Louis.
div.p: The cost of the Egyptian exhibit at the St. Louis Exposition brought to L.E. 5,043.

div.head: National Hotel.
div.p: The Band of the 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers will play on the terrance on Wednesday, 7th inst., instead of Friday, 9th.

div.head: Concert.
div.p: M. Paul Kochanski's second concert will take place at the New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria on Thursday next at 9.15 p.m.

div.head: Summer Uniforms.
div.p: The Ministry of War has given orders to the effect that the Army and Police should don their summer uniforms on the 1st May next.

div.head: Murder of a Khedivial Line Agent.
div.p: Last week Mr. Selim Cessar, the agent of the Khedivial Mail Line at Jaffa, was shot dead outside his house by a ghaffir, whom he had discharged.

div.head: The Late Marco Lavi Carasso.
div.p: The sons of the deceased Marco Levi Carasso have made a donation of twenty-five pounds to the British Benevolent Fund at Alexandria in memory of their father.

div.head: Savoy Small Dance.
div.p: Saturday's small dance at the Savoy was attended with the usual success. Over 250 persons dined in the restaurant before the dance, and the restaurant and the adjoining rooms were also crowded for supper.

div.head: Government Pensions.
div.p: The two English experts, who have been in Cairo on the subject of the new pension scheme, left yesterday for London. They will return next December to Egypt and will present their report to the Financial Adviser.

div.head: Suez Canal Dues.
div.p: At the annual meeting of the Chamber of Shipping of the United Kingdom held in London last week, a resoluation was adopted urging the executive council to persevere in their efforts to obtain reforms in regard to Suez Canal tonnage dues.

div.head: Notice.
div.p: We omitted to mention in our account in yesterday's issue of the inauguration of the Comptoir National d'Escompte de Paris at Alexandria that all the bronze counters, artistic glass-work, signs, etc., were made by Mr. H. Margosches of Alexandria, whose workmanship is excellent.

div.head: Sales of Palaces.
div.p: Adly Pacha Yaghen, has sold the Palace belonging to his wife at Kasr el-Nil for L.E. 120,000. It is also stated that one of the palaces of Prince Mohamed Aly Pacha has been sold for L.E. 53,000. The superficies of these palaces are respectively 6,600 and 7,200 sqaure metres.

div.head: Egyptian Thought-reader.
div.p: A great sensation has been created in America by a young Egyptian, who calls himself Khaldah and claims occult powers. He recently gave astonishing instances of acutal thought transference, or telepathy, at a private residence at New York. Requesting a member of the party to write several numbers and a name on paper, Khaldah asked this person to call up a certain number on the telephone and to inquire what numbers and what name were written on the paper. To the amazement of every one, the person at the other end of the line told, without making a mistake, the numbers and same written on the paper. This mysterious person at a distance, Khaldah admitted, was a friend of his.

div.head: Society Concert.
div.p: The "Society Concert" that is being organised in aid of the Blind Institution at Zeitoun, and is to take place on the 21st instant at Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo, promises to be a brilliant social function, and a musical entertainment of the highest class is in store for those fortunate enough to be present ; as the most talented of the amateur musicians in the country have promised their support and are busily engaged in rehearsing their parts. We understand there will be some very pretty glees, madrigals, and quartettes on the programme, that will bring to the fore some very notable songsters and musicians. As the concert has been placed under the distinguished patronage of H.H. the Khedive, the Rt. Hon. the Earl of Cromer, Major General G. M. Bullock, and is in the hands of a strong committee, composed of Messrs. A. D. Alban, E. A. Harrison, A. V. Thomson, G. Scott-Dalgleish, Kenneth Scott, M.D., and B. W. Jordan, its success is assured. We shall give notice later on of the programme but advise our readers to reserve Wednesday, 21set inst., for this musical treat, and at the same time assist one of the most deserving charities in the country.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON. AN IMPORTANT RISE IN PRICE.
div.p: A further important rise in the price of Egyptian cotton has taken place in Liverpool. The demand for the long-stapled descriptions has recently been unexampled in Lancashire, the Continent, and the States. The consumption of the cotton is increasing throughout the world.

div.head: GREECE AND EGYPT.
div.p: Athens advices state that the negotiations for the conclusion of a new commercial arrangement between Greece and Egypt are progessing in a satisfactory manner, both parties making mutual concessions, The Hellenic Government is confident of a successful termination of the negotiations.

div.p: The appeal made by the Sucreries Company against the decision of the Cairo Mixed Courts will be heard tomorrow (Wednesday).

div.head:
A CLEVER SWINDLER.
"BARON HERTENSTEIN."
HOW CAIRO TRADESMEN WERE "DONE."
div.p: A clever swindle was brought to light last Friday, when a supposed German, who had given his name as Baron Hertenstein, left Shepheard's for an unknown destination without paying his bill, after spending a week in one of that famous hotel's best apartments. Shepheard's Hotel, however, has not been the only place to suffer from the man's visit. There are but few firms in Cairo who have not received large orders from the supposed "Baron," but none of these have had their bills paid.

He figured prominently at the "Corso Masque" which was held at Ghezireh on the 25th ult, when he gained the first prize of £30 for an excellently decorated windmill car in which he sat disguised as a woman in a pink domino. In front of the car was a broad green ribbon on which was written in large gold letters "Mimi Gaillette, Chambre No. 116, Shepheard's," and he issued many invitations to dinner at Shepheard's to the admiring men with whom he gaily bandied words and exchanged showers of confetti. The design of the car and his costume were of the costliest, and he had also ordered another costume for the Ghezireh fancy-dress ball for which he owes a considerable sum of money to one of Cairo's best-known dressmakers.

The "Baron" leaves at Shepheard's Hotel, in lieu of the price of his bill, some ten pairs of boots, which was unpaid ; the Hotel de Suez holds a few travelling trunks which he had ordered from Messrs. Davies Bryan, and throughout his stay in Cairo he has ordered lavishly but paid for nothing.

It is not known exactly how this swindler escaped from Cairo but it is believed that on going to the station on Friday morning he had not sufficient courage to face the crowd there, many of whom would know him, and that he then drove to the Citadel, where he endeavoured to find a camel-driver who would be willing to take him as far as Benha, where he intended to take the train. In this he was unsuccessful and he then drove to the Bristol Hotel and dismissed the carriage of Shepheard's Hotel, in which he was driving, without payment. From there we have no trace of his movements but it is believed that he got safely to Alexandria or Port Said and embarked for a European port.
We understand that the police of the principal ports have been communicated with by telegraph and it is hoped that he will be arrested at whatever port he may disembark.

div.head: THE ROYAL VISIT.
div.p: T.R.H. the Prince and Princess of Wales will arrive at Suez on the 29th inst. and will proceed to Cairo by special train leaving at 12.30 p.m. and arriving in the Capital at 5.20 p.m.
On the 31st inst. the Princess of Wales will go by special train to Koubbeh, where she will pay a visit to the Khedivah mother and the Khedivah.
Their Royal Highnesses will leave Cairo on April 2 for an excursion to Bedrechein and on the 5th proxo. they will leave for Port Said, where they will embark on H.M.S. Renown.

div.head: NEW PALATIAL HOTEL FOR CAIRO.
div.p: The palace of Adly Pacha Yaghen, opposite the Kasr-el-Nil barracks, Cairo, containing over 6,000 sq. metres, has been sold for £8 per metre to the Ritz Hotel Company of Paris. A large, up-to-date, modern, first-class hotel is to be built on this magnificent site.

div.head: H.M.S. DONEGAL.
div.p: Suez, Monday.
H.M.S. Donegal returned to Suez from Ras Shuhair this morning at 7.30, and is now anchored in the Bay awaiting instructions from the Admiralty.
Although it is stated that the damage she sustained is slight, the ship may be ordered to proceed to Malta in order to be examined in dry-dock, the Suez one being too small.
Suez, Tuesday.
H.M.S. Donegal entered the Suez Canal today en route to Malta.

div.head: THE CLAN CUMMING RETURNS.
div.p: Suez, Monday.

The S.S. Clan Cumming, which will be remembered as being the "hero" of September last, when the S.S. Chatham had to be blown up in the Canal, arrived at Suez for the first time since the incident and entered the Canal this forenoon.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S. S. City Venice sailed yesterday for Liverpool direct with a general cargo including 5,815 bales cotton.
The Ellerman S. S. Alsatian sailed from Liverpool last Saturday for Lisbon, G. braltar, Malta, and Alexandria.
The Moss liner Tabor arrived at Liverpool on Sunday afternoon.
The S.S. Cyprian Prince, with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester last Sunday and is due to arrive at Alexandria, via Tunis and Malta, on or about March 21.

div.head: PORT SAID NOTES.
div.p: MANY TROOPSHIPS.

div.head: MINERVA GOES TO ASSIST THE DONEGAL.
div.p: Quite a number of troopships have passed through here daring the last few days. The Russian transports Malaya and Mercury, with together over 2,800 soldiers from Vladivostock, arrived on Monday, and left later for Odessa.
Some French troops were on board the Admiral Latoucbe Freville ; and subsequently, 700 Turkish soldiers, to reinforce Faizi Pache's army, passed throngb on the Turkish transport Tsib.

Owing to the 2nd class cruiser Donegal, which arrived here on Tuesday afternoon and proceeded shortly after on her way to the Far East, having gone ashore off Tor, H.M.S. Minerva left here early on Saturday morning to render assistance. As, however, the Donegal managed to get off the Minerva received orders to come back and arrived here yesterday afternoon.

The many people who paraded the town at carnival appeared to enjoy themselves and certainly appeared some amusement. Those on foot had to stand a good deal from the natives, and the latter had most of the fun. Tbe more fortunate, who could afford the luxury of a "buggy," had a good time but would have been better advised had they thrown more "oonfetti" and less haricot beans. A money-changer in the Rue de Commerce got a full charge, and has had his eye in a bandage ever since. Nothing is perhaps more beneficial than genuine fan, bit some steps should be taken to control people who cannot control themselves when out for a lark. They should not be allowed to think that real fun consists in doing harm to persons or property. Mardi Gras has come and gone, so we can do nothing now but sympathise with the injured ; on future occasions, however, the police should be instructed to prevent the throwing of haricot beans, or other sorts of so-called confetti, that are likely to cause injury.

div.head:
NILE VALLEY CO.
THE RECONSTRUCTION SCHEME.
div.p: In view of the legal obstacle to the reconstruction proposal of the Nile Valley Company the directors are formulating a new scheme without exceptional provisions as regards any dissentient shareholders, who will then have the usual right to be paid off at a valuation. We understand that it is intended to call the meeting to consider the new scheme for some date next week.
Mr. Justice Kekewich a few days ago, declined to sanction the reconstruction scheme.

His Lordship, in giving judgment, said he could not see how the old company or the liquidator could compel a shareholder to take shares in the new company, whether it was his rateable proportion or not, and imposing thereby a liability. Under this scheme an attempt was made to get over that. Under this scheme those shareholders willing to accept partly-paid shares in the new company could get them. Then came a difficulty as to what was to be done with those who would not accept the new shares. They could not be forced to accept them, and they were entitled to their share of the assets of the company in their proper proportion. It was proposed, under this scheme, if some of the shareholders obstinately refused—and they were entitled to be obstinate if they chose—to take the shares to the new company they were to have something else. What was that something else? If the shares in the new company were not taken up by the contributors to the old company they were to be sold by the liquidator within a certain period. There seemed no objection to a reasonable time limit, but the liquidator was to sell not necessarily all at once, but to sell them as he could. At any rate, he was to sell. If eventually they were sold for an "old song," they had to go, as the shares had to be realised and the amount distributed after deducting expenses among the shareholders dissenting from the arrangement. That might prove extremely unfair to some of them, for some of the shares might be sold at a good price, while the others sold for an "old song.'' But those whose shares were sold for practically nothing were to get the same portion as those whose shares had realised a high price. That seemed to be unfair and unjust. Apart from that, however, it seemed to be telling the dissenting shareholders that if they did not come into the scheme they would only get a proportion, whatever it might be, of the sale of these shares held by the dissentient shareholders. But if they did come in they would have to accept the new shares with their liability. That seemed unfair. It seemed that the scheme in question took away what belonged to the shareholders. In the circumstance he proposed to restrain the defendant company from carrying out the agreement as it stood. How far it would succeed in another form he could not say, but it was unacceptable as it was.

div.head: Isherwood's Cairo Cigarettes.
div.p: The reputation which these Cigarettes have gained in the past, stands unrivalled today, because it is well-known that constant care and attention is devoted to supplying treally first-class Cigarettes only.
Between the Bristish Consulate and Turf Club.

div.head:
THE CAIRO SEASON.
ON THE WANE.
TALK OF HOMEWARD JOURNEY.
div.p: A fortnight ago the season was in its zenith. Today one begins to feel that all good things come to an end and that it will not be many weeks before Cairo again sinks into its six months' sleep of summer. A certain number of familiar figures will be no more seen after today, and the spirit of unrest is in the air and many plans are being made for the return journey and for other meetings in the future and under far different conditions.

Mrs Armstrong, who has been such an indefatigable hostess all winter at the Savoy, is leaving today for England, and at the same time are leaving Mr. Acton Adams and his attractive niece, Miss Collins, and also Mrs. Smart and her daughter, who have both been so exceedingly popular daring their stay. There will be a good many more departures before the middle of the month, but it is to be hoped that the visit of the Prince and Princess of Wales will induce the greater proportion of visitors to remain till April. The Prince and Princess are expected on March 29, and their visit will last in all probability for just under the week. Preparations are being made for their reception at Abdeen Palace, and everything will be done to make their stay a memorable one.

Four hundred dinners were served in the Savoy Hotel on Saturday night, but nevertheless the ball-room was never uncomfortably hot. The big fancy-dress ball at Ghezireh and the two private balls held last week probably exhausted the energies of a good number of dancers and others were receiving themselves for the fancy-dress ball at the Savoy this evening.

A most regrettable incident occurred at the dance on Saturday night when a visitor chose to complain to the leader of the orcestra on the qaality of the music and in the heat of the moment made use of language highly uncomplimentary to M. Bracale and most unsuitable to the society in which he found himself. Such contretemps are not always avoidable, but it is always a matter of regret when a visitor, and presumably a gentlemen, so far forgets himself in a public assembly.

div.head: KEHDIVIAL OPERA HOUSE.
div.p: "IRIS."

Iris is an opera which hardly repays the curosity that sends one to see it. For music it gives the impression of a rechanffes of Tosca, with a strong suspicion of Cavalleria now and again: it has about the same place in music as patchouli in perfumes, a sustained, fictitious, and wearisome attempt at emotion. The plot has some merit, and is suggestive: that is hardly an excuse for the piece, as one naturally assumes that a more than commonplace composer chooses something abnormal to carry off other futilities. Still, per se, apart from all else, the plot is worth word instead of the absurdly normal magazine story of Madame Butterfly and such like eftusions, we have the idea, the absolute ignorance of the Japanese child who cries over her bad dreams and broken doll, who wails, like Melisande: all the lover can obtain from her is 'je ne suis pas heureuse." Her father's curse at the end frightens her, she only realises that he is angry, and she throws herself down to her death as a child would throw itself on the ground in tears ; and her death-song is the longing for happiness of which she knows nothing, the praise of the sun which she cannot see behind its cloud. There it a faint touch of eternity in the story.

The interpretation was not much better or worse than that usually given in the Khedivial Opera House. The principals were mostly good, especially Iris herself and the tenor, who has a nice "timbre." The staging ires good, and the chorus better than usual. But it is hardly a piece to see twice what with the languid music which never means anything, which wakes the listener with a start of momentary expectation, only to find that the phrase has collapsed into yet another wave of mediocrity. It is lukewarm, and Laodicean, and not worthy of the story.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: H.R.H. Prince Chakrabong of Siam and suite, including Phya Sridhamaeasans, the Siamese Minister, arrived at Port Said on Sunday night and stayed at the Savoy Hotel. His Royal Highness embarked yesterday morning on the North German Lloyd S.S. Prinz Eitel Friedrich.

The Archduke Joseph and Archduchess Augusta of Austria arrived at Alexandria this morning by the Norddeutacher Lloyd S.S. Schleswig and proceeded to Cairo in a special saloon carriage placed at their disposal by H.H. the Khedive.
H.E. the Sirdar will arrive in Cairo next Monday.
Bishop Biyth left Alexandria for Cairo this morning, and leaves Egypt for Jaffa tomorrow.
Hussein Pacha Fakhry, Minister of Public Works, is giving a big dinner on Thursday, 15th inst., at the Savoy Hotel.

Count Thadde Bolesta Kodzlebrodski, Austro-Hungarian Diplomatic Agent and Consul General, gave a dinner yesterday evening in one of the private dining-rooms of the Savoy Hotel. His guests were: Baron and Baroness de Rucker Jenisch, M. and Mme de la Bouliniere, Mlle Charlotte de la Bouliniere, Mlle Autoinette de la Bouliniere, Comte and Comtesse da Sierstorpff, Comte and Comtesse da Wedel, Mms de Balthazzi Stockau, Mlle Balthazzi, Comte E. de Bethyany, Duc de Cirella, M. A. B. de Gnerville, M. Robert de Guerville, and Comte A. Stadnicky.

Mrs. Pidgeon entertained a party to dinner at the Savoy Restaurant yesterday evening, the guests including : Dr. and Mrs. Milton, Mr. and Mrs. Garner, Mr. and Mrs. Sharman, Mr. Le Breton, Mr. Russell, Mr. Courtney Clifton, Miss Amos, Mr. Allen, Miss de Bilinski, Mrs. Bell White, and Miss Babington Jones.
The infant daughter of Sir Francis Wingate will "cut the cake" at the birthday celebration of the British and Foreign Bible Society at the Guidhall a week hence. The Lord Mayor will preside.

Sir Frederick Treves is coming out to Egypt for a holiday. Let us hope, the "Telegraph" remarks, that be will take advantage of his trip to give the world some more of the vivid word-pictures which so many enjoyed in his volume "The Other Side of the Lantern." His address as Lord Rector of the University of Aberdeen more than sustained his reputation as a public speaker. Lord Rosebery said years ago at a complimentary banquet to the eminent surgeon that if he were to enter the political arena he would challenge our foremost orators.
Mr. C. Chapman, inspector of buildings in the Government Buildings Department of the Ministry of Public Works, will retire from the Government service tomorrow for reasons of health.
Mr. H. Favarger, the well-known architect, has left London for a three-months' trip to the United States.

The following passengers travelled to Upper Egypt by the train de luxe last night :––Mr. Pecke and party of 3, Mr. and Mrs. Fabricotti, Mr. O. Blythes, Mr. Gosling, Miss Blyth, Mr. Beckett, Mr. H. Tambed, Mr. G. Meyer, Mr. Kentner, Mme Thomas, Mr. and Mme Pepper, Mr. Slaughter, Judge Piggott, Mr. Barsoum Chalabi and family, Cook's Moltke party of 15.

div.head: OBITUARY.
div.p: Sir Frederick Horniman is dead. (Reuter)

div.head: DEATH.
div.p: HEWENS.–– At Alexandria, on the 5th inst., William Walter Hewens, aged 31.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie)
Le marche a montre one animation exceptionnelle ce matin. Les valeurs les plus echangees ont ete la Banque d'Athenes, les Estates, les Nungovich et les Ordinary Khedivial Mail.
La Banque d'Athenes s'est avancee a 145 ex, les Estates a 1 31/32 les actions et a 9 1/4 les parts de fondateur, les Nungovich a 15 13/16 et les Ordinary Khedivial Mail a 45/6.
Ce sont les Nungovich qui ont eu la hausse la plus marquante, soit 1 livre 1/4.
En hausse egalement les Egyptian Hotels a 5 1/4, la Filature a 1 £, les Tramways d'Alexandrie a 166, les New Egyptian a 30/3 et les Crown Brewery a 215 1/2.
Par contre, il s'est produit une reaction legere en Cassa di Sconto a 205 1/2 et on Salt & Soda a 25/6.
La Delta Light est momentanement delaissee a 12 3/8.
Le Banco di Roma, nonvellement inscrit a la cote, a ete pratique entre 125 et 126.

div.head:
THE KING IN PARIS.
DINNER AT THE EMBASSY.

div.p: Princess Ena and her mother lunched with King Edward at the British Embassy. His Majesty afterwards called on M. Faillieres and conversed with him for half an hour. The President returned the visit immediately. His Majesty gave a dinner in the Embassy in the evening at which M and Madame Fallieres, M and Madame Reuter and a few others, including Baron de Lource were present. The latter, after he has received by the Enperor William at Copemigen, went to Berlin, where he again met the Emperor and conferred with Count von Bulow. (See despatch of the 19th February).
King Edward invited M. Loubet to dinner today. (Reuter)
King Edward lunched with M. Loubet and M. Delcasse at the Embassy. (Reuter)
King Edward gave a luncheon at the British Embassy to M. Leubet and M. Delcasse.
The Princess of Battenberg have left for San Sebastian. King Alfonso came to the Angoultme to meet them. (Havas)
The Bishop of Nottingham will also attend Princess Ena's reception into the Catholic Church. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE NATAL TROUBLES.
A CHIEF CAPTURED.

div.p: The police and the mounted infantry have captured the chief Gobizembe, who failed to surrender, and a recalcitrant tribesman. His kraal was shelled after clearing out the inhabitants. 40 headmen then came in to make their submission. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE SOKOTO RISING.
MAHDI DIES OF HIS WOUNDS.

div.p: Sir F. Lugerd reports from Sokoto that the Mahdi is said to have died of his wounds. The rebels are surrounded by a native contingent from Sokoto. Ample reinforcements will reach the latter in a few days. The loyalty of all the emirs is a most striking feature. (Reuter)
The Russian delegates have submitted the exposition of a police project which will come on for discussion on Thursday. (Havas)
The "Daily Telegraph" learns from Tokio that the British and French Ministers have made strong representations to Peking in reference to the Nanchang massacres, demanding full compensation. (Reuter)
The English journalist Kennard while touring in the disturbed provinces has been arrested at Orel. The British Consal at Moscow has communicated with the Embassy at St. Petersburg. (Reuter)

Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman has announced that, owing to the inability of Mr. Balfour and Mr. Chamberlain to be present, it will be necessary to postpone the discussion of the fiscal question till the 12th instant. (Reuter)
The Admiralty is taking out a policy of insurance for about £10,000,000 against losse-through detention of merchantmen which may co-operate in the great naval maneuvres this summer. (Reuter)

div.head:
A TERRIBLE STORM.
LARGE FISHING FLEET SCATTERED.

div.p: A fishing fleet of about 400 boats has been scattered by a terrible storm. Most of them succeeded in resching harbour but 34 are known to have been lost. (Reuter)
The peasants of Cevennes are offering resist arcs to the inventories of the churches. They made use of their guns. (Havas)
Mme. Constans, wife of the Ambassador, is dead. (Havas)

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit –– within certain necessary limits –– free discussion.

div.head: ANTEDILUVIAN METHODS AT THE POST OFFICE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—I think that all those who have visited Egypt during a good many years past must agree in admiring the way in which the Post Office usually carries out its work, a work which in this country must be beset by special difficulties. Three languages, Arabic, French, (the official tongue), and English (the dominant) are always to the fore. In the winter what a congregation of visitors, speaking and receiving letters written in many varieties of tongues! How we expect our letters to follow us hither and thither and how well all this is managed! And how exceedingly civil and helpful one finds the postmasters even in the most out-of the-way places.
Now for the inevitable "but."

But, Sir, there is a thing which the post office professes to do and does, in a way which leaves not a little to be desired. It professes to convey and deliver to post offices of a certain degree money "in group," that is, a bag fall of cash. There are in Egypt but a very few towns. We can almost count them on the fingers of our two hands, but the face of the country is dotted over in all directions with villages. It is not until you have been establishing work, and until you have to pay wages regularly in small coin, that you realize how hard it often is to get change even for a sovereign in these villages. Here, at El Kab, I an about 10 miles from one post town, Edfu, and 20 from another, Esna. My post office at Mahamid is naturally of the simplest and at our railway station it is not infrequently difficult to get change for a sovereign. I am forced to have silver and nickel from Cairo, "in group," which I receive at Edfu. The mail train with its letters and parcels comes every day, and offers all reasonable conveniences, I am but 18 hours post from Cairo. But if a "group" is sent a complete change comes over the scene.

In December last I sent to the Bank of Egypt for a "gronp" to be delivered for me at Edfu. On the 20th the money was sent from Cairo, but not until the 29th does it arrive at Edfu, to which place I send. From the time I write (the 18th) to the time I receive is 12 days. Recently it has taken from the 19th to the 25th February to send from Cairo to Edfu—5 days. From the time 1 write till the time I receive 8 days. On enquiry I am told that the money comes by train to Luxor, but at that place the old and exploded post boat comes into operation. The group must wait at Luxor until the next boat turns up and by that conveyance it comes to Edfu although the railway station is just across the river.—I am, etc,

div.head: WE BEG YOUR PARDON MA'AM.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
Dear Sir,—In two issues of the "Egyptian Gazette" I read about that shameful act of the students stopping a lady, when she meant their benefit, from speaking to them her opinion.
Certainly she has been led by her sympathies, saw it her duty, and so she is obliged for human's sake to help them in, what we may say, their critical position, in seeing the right way.
And, Sir, they have been unthankful and uncourteous to her most moral help, and met her with what you term "conspuee et ex pulsee."

Please, Sir, do you think that any barbarian would do such an act, not an Egyptian Student! We may be ignorant of the laws of etiquette, but we are never unrespectful to ladies. Could you believe the thing then?
Certainly no, is it not most absurd? Who could believe it? None!
Then permit me, Sir, to say, it is an invention of a silly head who has done much unjustice to the students, than the new regulations of the School of Law.
div.dateline: School of Medecine, Kasr el-Aini, Cairo.

div.head: FIT FOR "PUNCH"
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,—May I ask if you fully realised the sarcasm of your paragraph about "a motor road to Khanka which is considered to have many advantages, especially in view of the growing importance of that locality owing to the establishment of a great lunatic asylum there."
The connection is obvious, however uncomplimentary to the motoris's. Easy access to a suitable destination. No return tickets. Yours, &c,

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Colonel Marling, V.C., 10th Hussars, having vacated the command of that regiment, the command has been given to a well known North Country officer, Lieutenant-Colonel Pollok Morris, whilst the vacant majority has been filled by this promotion of Captain Charles H. Leveson, presently employed with the Egyptian Army. Major Leveson remains on promotion with the Egyptian Army. It is over 16 years since he first joined the 18th, and he reached his late rank just six years ago. He was employed with the West African Regiment, 1899-1901, and took up his present employment three years ago. He has had considerable experience of active service, beginning with the Chitral Relief Expedition (medal with clasp), to which he added two additional clasps for the Tirah Expedition three years later. Whilst attached to the West Africa Regiment, he saw service in Ashanti (medal with clasps) and in the winding up of the Boer War he was with the 18th in the drives and operations in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony, and along the Zululand borders of Natal, in the course of which he was severely wounded (mentioned in despatches, Queen's medal with four clasps).

Major H. D. A. Harkness, C.B., Welsh Regiment, who for a considerable period was attached to the Egyptian Army, will shortly succeed Colonel Dickinson in command of the 2nd Battalion at Quetta, Bombay. Major Harkness during his service with the Khedive's troops participated in the Sudan operations of 1889, for which he received the medal, star, and 4th Class Osmanieh.

Lientenant P. R. Napier, Army Service Corps, who has been serving for some time with the 54th Company, Portsmouth, has been placed unders orders to join at Cairo in relief of Lieutenant Bleucowe, who has joined the Khedive's Army. Lieutenant Napier originally was gazetted to the Scottish Rifles in 1899, and was transferred to the A.S.C. on the New Year's day of 1902. He was with the Army Service Corps, as an attached officer, in the Transvaal campaign, 1901-02 (Queen's medal with two clasps).

Lieutenant C. F. N. Bartlett, Royal Berkshire Regiment, recently doing duty with the 2nd Battalion at Khartoum, has resigned his commission in that regiment. Mr. Bartlett joined the Royal Berks, in April, 1900, from the 3rd Battalion Oxfordshire Light Infantry, then embodied at Buttevant, Ireland.
Orders have been issued for the infantry brigades on home service, from the 9th to the 14th, to receive the new short rifle and bandolier equipment.

In the near future the German naval superiority to France will become conspicuous unless a special effort at once be made to counteract the activity in German dock-yards. It is interesting to note that the world at largo, and England in particular, cannot be indifferent to any marked decline in the relative strength of the French navy. The prevent friendly relations between France and England only slightly effect the question. All such pleasant relations are liable to change, but the maintenance of the balance of sea power affords a guarantee of European peace.

La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture de gargouilles pour trottoirs avec accessoires.
Le cautionnement est fixe à L.E. 40.
Le cahier des charges est déposé au Bureau de la Voirie ou il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. a midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administration de la Municipalité avant le 3 Avril prochain.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour a 5 h. p.m.
L'Enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour fourniture de gargouilles pour trottoirs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'onne banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 3 Avril prochain a midi.

L'Administrateur (Signe) W. P. CHATAWAY.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ART.
THE SPONTANEOUS PERIOD.
PROF. PETRIE'S THIRD LECTURE.
div.p: Prof. Flinders Petrie gave the third of his lectures on Egyptian Art at the Continental Hotel, Cairo, yesterday afternoon. The subject was that of the rise of the and it is of spontaneous growth. During the prehistoric age art could hardly be said to there was no accurate appreciation of such as there was in the prehistoric age of Europe. The oldest figures of men that are known in thin country are two fighters, rudely outlined on a vase, belonging to the first prehistoric age of pottery. The most able work of the prehistoric people are some heads carved on ivory tusks, which shew the type of that race, with tall heads, long beards, and aquiline noses. The enormous change which came in with the conquest by the dynastic race between 6000 and 500 B. C. is a vary strong proof of the entry of a different race into the country. The oldest example of their work, the rude figures of Koptos, have spiritual figures of animals. The series of slate carvings which commemorate the conquestt of the land are of admirable vigour. And one of these bears the first piece of pure art known in Egypt : the graceful figures of two long-necked gazelles, standing either side of a palm tree, show the beginning of one of the best known designs of all ages, the tree and two supporters. When we enter the historic times the article taste and technical skill of the bracelets of the reign of king Zer strike us with astonishment. The fine design, each entirely different from the others, the freedom of work, and the perfection of the soldering of the gold, all shew that the Egyptians had already a mastery in jewellery as early as the beginning of the first dynasty.

The drawing of the pyramid period was rather hard but very accurate at first; in the Vth and VIth dynasties it fell off. The earliest good example is that of the well-known geese from Medum. The scenes in the tomb of Ti at Sakkara are spirited; and the group of fighting boatmen in the Cairo Museum shows how readily the artists could step outside of conventions that were arising. An interesting series of subjects outside of the usual line are the scenes of bargaining in a tomb. The sculpture in the round was the principal artistic expression of the early kingdom. Even before Menes there were large numbers of ivory figures carved and one of the most subtle of those ivory carvings is that of an aged king of about the period of Menes.

This shows how early the expression of character had been effected and the accidents of surroundings subordinated to the feeling of the whole. The reliefs of the wooden panels of Hesy show the result of round work in the high projection and fine modelling of the figures. Beside this work there was also a somewhat different school, which affected a more archaic style, with staring eyes and a heavy expression, as the statue of Mertiteps the queen of Seneferu at Leyden. The figures of Rahotep and Nefart in the Cairo Museum show the rise of the noble style of the pyramid builders. The character is carefully treated ; and the contrast is well shown between the anxious and responsible expression of the king's son, with the dignified and commanding style of the princess who has always had her wishes obeyed. The statuette of Khufu, the builder of the great pyramid, small as it is, shews extra ordinary power of treatment. The grip and determination is unrivalled in any later work in Egypt, or perhaps in the world. The dignified statue of Khafra, the builder of the second pyramid, is on much the rame lines as the figure of Khufu as regards the massive body, but the head is much more suave and refined in its type. The work is perhaps the most exalted in style that we know in Egypt, most remote from mere passion, and most nobly shewing forth the beneficent autocrat, king and god of his country.

It was not only the great rulers who were thus immortalised, the lesser officials also are shewn with their own characters and manners. The well-known wooden statue has perhaps the greatest popularity, with his bon hommis and business air. But the fellow figure of a woman is a higher piece of art, with a mixture of impetuosity and shrewdness which is extraordinarily life-like. A totally different character is seen in the scribe figures. The scribe in the Louvre is the alert man of business, the thinker of daily affairs, without ideals, but watchful to every torn of fortune. The scribe in the Cairo Mnsenm is more easy-going, but with the same observant ready air. The humble attendant on his lord who kneels with folded hands, and obsequious face, in the Cairo Museum is yet another different kind of man. And the low class serving women grinding the corn in the Florence Museum shows the hard working housewife, without any of the abilities of those already noticed. The statue of a great noble Nenkhept-ka shows yet again the high type of the able administrator, shrewd but kindly. All of those figures impress us with the versatility and grasp of character shown by the Egyptian artist. The work is nowhere copied from general types but is intensely individual in expression and spontaneous in its nature.

The metal work was also highly developed. The fine gold hawk's head of the VIth dynasty is wrought in a facile material. But the large upper figures of Pepy and his son are triumph of expression, as life like as some of the best Roman work. The technical difficulties of working the metal by hammering vet with such truth and exactness, make us admire the more the freedom and spirit of the artist. The view of the early and best age of Egyptian art shows how it stands as perfect as any of the other great schools of art, and superior to almost all others. It also makes us feel how great was the declension to the better ages and how the vulgar notion of it is infinitely below the grand and noble works of the great age of this land.

div.head: BRITISH TRADE IN THE LEVANT.
div.p: An extraordinary general meeting of the British Chamber of Commerce of Turkey has just been held at Constantinople in pursuance of the following demand. signed by five directors:

"That in view of the tremendous and successful efforts of our commercial rivals owing to their up-to date and well-organized diplomatic and consular system to protect and promote the interests of their trader and their enterprise in Eastern countries such as Turkey, it is in combent on his Majesty's Government to take into serious consideration a change in its present diplomatic and consular system in its relation to British trade, and to improve and adapt it to modem exigencies."

This meeting proved of the greatest interest to all commercially connected with the Near East. It has been a complaint of long standing that British trade with the Balkans showed very little elasticity and expansion, whereas the imports of other countries, especially Germany, increased by leaps and bounds. The British Chamber of Commerce on Constantinople, in various meetings, has laid the blame for this state of affairs apon what they call an 'antiquated and inefficient Diplomatic and Consular Service," whereas many impartial observers were of the opinion that British manufacturers had done nothing, while the German and other manufacturers had done everything to secure for themselves the markets of the Balkans. Although frequently urged to do so British manufactures and merchants have failed to make systematic and concentrated efforts to win the Balkan market. In consequence British trade in the Balkans has been pushed more and more into the background, while other countries have superseded England's formerly dominant position there.

div.head: IMPORTS OF COTTON YARN TO EGYPT.
div.p: An instruetive table is published by the "Manchester Guardian" showing in thousands of pounds the amount of cotton yarn and twist exported from Great Britain daring 1903, 1904 and 1905 respectively, with the average value per pound for each of the countries. From this it appears Russia is easily first in the quality of the yarns taken, the imports amounting to 557,000 lbs. with an average value last year of 30 66d. per lb., while Egypt has the lowest average in the same year. viz, 8.59d. on a total import of 4,381,000lbs. In 1904 Egypt imported 4,381,000lbs. with an average value of 9.83d. and in 903 we received 4,590,000 with an average of 8.06d.

div.head: ABYDOS III.
div.p: In the "Revuedel' Histoire des Religions" there is a review of Messrs. Ayton and Correlly's publication 'Ahydos III.,' wherein M. G. Foucart points out that their discovery of the funnerary chapel and stela of Teta Shera c'ears up the mystery which has hither to hung over the ancestry of Ashmes I, the founder of the glorious Eighteenth dynasty. This king, who finally delivered his country from the role of the hated Hyksos, was, according to M. Foncart, the son of Sequenenra the fierce Sudani prince who first threw off the Hyksos yoke, by Aah-hetep who was probably of the ancient royal blood of Egypt. Aah-hetep's mother was the Teta Shera last mentioned, and by Sequene-ra she had Aahmes's predecessor Kames, and by a subsequent husband the celebrated Nefert-ari, whom Aahmes married. The great prominence and the divine honours given in later Egyptian times to the queens of Aahmes's family, and especially to Nefert-ari, lend much colour to M. Foncart's view.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: A remarkable change has taken place in the weather during the past 24 hours. After a spell of delightful weather, which continued till yesterday morning, ominous clouds gathered and the wind rose, increasing as the day advanced to the force of a strong gale. At night heavy gales prevailed, the wind having the velocity of 90 kilmetres. The morning opened dull and there was some heavy rain, with a moderate gale from N.W. The barometer is now rising and warmer conditions should prevail today.

div.head: COMITE DE PROTECTION DES CREANCIERS
REGLEMENT D'ORGANIZATION
div.p: L'Association du Commerce d'Importation offre au Commerce Egyptien de le representer dans toute procedure de faillite ou de concordat preventit, ainsi qu'a l'occasion de toute sus pension de paiement ou proposition d'arrange ment amiable, qui se verifierait dans le ressort du Tribunal Mixte d'Alexandrie.
Et ce dans le but :
1 de representer les interets des cranciers ;
2 de faciliter aux creanciers la production et la defense de leurs creances ;
3 de leur assurer un meme et egal dividende ;
4 d'empecher que leurs droits soient le es par tous agissements frauduleux ou commercialement reprehensibles.
A ces effets, l'Association du commerce d'Importation cree dans se proure de l'organisation suivante :
I

Il est institue un Comite permanent, intitule "Comite de Protection des Creanciers", forme de dix-huit membres effectifs et six suppleants, a elire au commencement de chaque annee sociale par 1'Assemblae geuerale de l'Association du Commerce d'lmportation.
Tont membre de l'Association est eligible
II

Le Comite de Protection des Creanciers se divisera en six Sous-Commissions, composees de trois membres chacune, lesquelles siegeront a tour de role et pour l'espace de deux mois consecutifs pour chaque role.
La formation des Sous-Commissions et la distribution des roles seront etablies au commencement de 1'annee dans une reunion speciale des membres elus.
Les membres du Comite de Protection des Creanciers sont reeligibles.
III

Les Sous-Commissions auront a s'occuper, suivant les modalites ci-bas specifiees, de toute faillite, concordat preventif ou simple suspension de paiements qui se verifierait pendant les deux mois de leur role respectif; et ce jusqu'a conclusion d'arrangement amiable, homologation de concordat ou cloture de faillite.
Les Sous-Commissions devront etre toujours entierement composees de membres non creanciers du debiteur dont le cas leur sera soumis.
Par consequent, sur leur invitation, le President de l'Association du Commerce d'lmportation pourvoira aux remplacements necessaires parmi les autres membres du Comite de Protection des Creanciers.
IV

Le President de l'Association du Commerce d'Importation represente en chaque procedure de faillite ou de concordat preventif ou suspension de paiement les adherents a l'organisation presentement creee.

Chaque adherent admis devra par consequent faire tenir au President de l'Association du Commerce d'Importation procuration speciale aux effets cidesaus et pour la periode d'une annee, suivant formu'e etablie par le Comite.
V

Tout adherent qui serait a connaissance de la faillita ou de la suspension de paiements declaree d'un de ses debiteurs, devra en preve nir aussitot le President de l'Association du Commerce d'lmportation, lequel en informera la Sous-Commission siegeante.
VI
La Sous-Commission aura soin d'obtenir du Greffe du Tribunal Mixte de Commerce connaissance immediate de tout depot de bilan ou declaration de faillite.
Elle en donners aussitos avis a tons les adherents dont les noms figureront sur la liste des creanciers, en les invitant par lettre recommandee:
1. a lui remettre bordereau de creance et pieces a l'appui;
2. a intervenir a une reunion a laquelle ils auront:
a) a exposer leurs vues sur la situation;
b) a se prononcer sur le maintiendes Syndics, la nomination de co-syndics on d'experts;
c) a proposer d'un a trois creanciers pour former la delegation prevue par la Loi.
Tout adherent creancier pourra emettre son vote par lettre, ou se faire representer par deiegation speciale.
Les decisions sont prises a la majority des voix : en cas de nombre egal, le sort designera.
La resultat du vote est obligatoire pour tous les adherents, y compris les absents.
VII
A partir de la declaration de faillite on du depot du bilan, les creanciers adherents ne pourront traiter personnellement aucun accord avec le debiteur ou tout tiers, ni ceder leurs creances.
VIII

La Sous-Commission pourvoira par les soins du Contentieux a toutes les procedures judiciaires et extrajudiciaires jusqu'a conclusion d'arrangement amiable, homologation de concordat ou cloture de faillite.
Elle recevra tous les renseignements que les adherents creanciers voudront bien lui donner sur la situation du debiteur, sa bonne foi, les causes de la cessation des paiements, e'c.
Elle prendra vision et copie de tout rapport des Syndics, des experts on des delegations des creanciers.
Les rapports seront a la disposition des interesses dans les bureaux de l'Association du Commerce d'Importation sans deplacement.
Trois jours au moins avant la seance de concordat, la Sous-Commission se prononcera sur son acceptation ou son rejet.
La decision de la Sous-Commission est obligatoire pour tons les adherents : elle sera transmise au President de l'Association du Commerce d'Importation et au Contentieux lequel agira en consequence.
IX
Tout creancier adherent qui serait nanti d'hypotheque ou de gage devra en donner avis a la Sous-Commission, des la reception de la lettre prevue aus VI.
X

Pour couvrir les frais que la presente organisation entrainera, tout adherent payera a l'Association du Commerce d'Importation le deux et demi pour cent du dividende arrete sur le montant da ses creances, a l'exclusion des creances privilegiees.
XI
La demande d'admission entraine l'adhesion pleine et entiere au present reglement.
XII
Toute contravention aux obligations ci-dessus aas specifiees, ainsi que tout acte tendant a entraver le fonctionnement de la presente organisation, entraluera la radiation du contrevenant.
XIII
La declaration en etat de failliet d'un adherent entraine sa radiation.
XIV
La radiation sera prononcee par le Comite de Protection des Creanciers, convoque en seance pleniere et a la majorite des membres presents.
Tout membre demissionnaire on raye reste toutefois soumis aux obligations resultant du present reglement jusqu'a la fin des procedures entamees avant sa demission on sa radiation.
XV
Les fonctions des membres du Comite de Protection des Creanciers sont gratuites.
XVI
Le Comite de Protection des Creanciers se reserve d'etendre son action au ressort des Tribunaux Mixtes de Mansourah et du Caire.

div.head: LA FAILLITE DES SUCRERIES
div.p: Voici les principaux attendus et le dispositif du jugement rendu samedi par la Chambre commerciale du Tribunal Mixte du Cairo declarant la Societe des Sucreries en etat de faillite.

… Attendu que la Societe debitrice soutient qu'il y a une distinction a faire entre la Societe, etre moral personnifant les actionnaires, et les administrateurs ses representants ; qu'a l'appui elle expose qu'il s'agit d'une societe anonyme composes de 325,000 actions, dont une tres petite proportion aux mains des administrateurs et que personne n'allegne la mauvaise foi des actionnaires qui, frappes de pertes imprevues et impossibles a prevoir, sont par consequent des debiteurs malheureux; qu'elle ajoute que les administrateurs mandataires de l'assemblee generale, revocables a tout moment, ne peuvent etre confondus avec les mandants ; qu'il importe pen que le mandat soit d'une nature speciale, et a concurrence des actions qu'ils possedent et qu'on ne saurait pretendre que si cette societe a ete trompee par ses mandataires elle devient indigne du concordat preventif et subit ainsi une veritable penalite ;
Attendu que ni la Societe ni les creanciers n'ont cite le texte d'un auteur quelconque a l'appui de leur systeme de defense et que la jurisprudence belge y est contraire……
Par ces motifs :
Oui le juge-commissaire en son rapport et le ministere public en ses conclusions ;
Recoit lit l'intervention des creanciers representes par Me Carton de Wisrt, Padoa bey et Saint Plancat ;
Et statuant contradictoirement, ecartant toutes autres conclusions ;
En consequence declare en etat de faillite la Societe generale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte, Societe anonyme egyptienne ayant son siege social au Caire.
Fixe provisoirement la date de la cessation de ses paiements au 28 aout 1905 date indiquee dans le proces verbal de depot du bilan.
Nomme comme juge-commissaire M. Tuck, president de cette chambre et comme syndic M. Sampaolo.
Ordonne l'apposition des scelles sur les facultes mobilieres de la dite Societe en faillite. Frais a la charge de la masse.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire, 5 mars.

A Londres, le Consolide anglais a cloture avant hier a 90 1/2, soit en hausse de 1/8. L'Unifiec, la National Bank et la Doira Sanieh sont restees invariees. L'Agricole est renseignee en reprise de 1/8 a 10.
A Paris, le Credit Foncier Egyptian est demeure inchange a 792. La Banque d'Athenes a reactionne de 1 franc a 146.
Ici, nous avons eu ce matin un marche tres anime et tres ferme, avec des cours en hausse sur beaucoup de valeurs.

La National Bank, delaissee, a cloture au meme prix que samedi passe ; l'action nouvelle a fait 26 9/16. L'Agricole s'est inscrite a 10 1/8 l'action ancienne et 9 11/16 la nouvelle. La Cassa di Sconto a avance a 208 l'action ancienne et a 205 la nouvelle.
L'action Credit Foncier est restee a 792 ; les obligations a lots 1886 ont progresse a 338,339. La Behera a cloture a 38 1/4.

L'action Immobiliere a encore gagne 8 francs a 385 ; la part de fondateur est a 500 acheteurs. L'action Agricole du Nil rest montee a 279 ; l'action Enterprise and Development a 12 9/16. On sait que la nouvelle emission a lieu au cours de 12 livres.
Les Sucreries sont tombees a 16 vendeurs.
Les privilegiees Tramways d'Alexandrie ont progresse a 165 ; l'action ordinaire Khedivial Mail a 41 sh. 6.
Le groupe des Hotels a ete tres mouyemente. Les Nungovich ont cloture a 14 5/8. Les Baehler ont egalement hausse a 5 5/8 acheteurs.

Le conseil d'administration de cette Societe a decide, parait-il, de realiser sans retard les projets qu'il etudiait depuis quelque temps. Ainsi le Shepheard's Hotel sera agrandi par la construction d'une aile qui comportera 200 chambres et appartements. D'autre part, le Ghezireh Palace sera transforme. On creera, notamment, sur le Nil, une terrasse longue de 50 metres, appelee a devenir le but de promenade favori du Caire non seulement en hiver, mais encore en ete, ou l'on y jouira d'use temperature delicieuse.
Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land avancent a 3 3/16, les Hookor a 1 1/16—3/32, et les Estates a 1 29/2. Les Egyptian Constructions reviennent a 1 7/16—1/2.

C'est ce matin qu'a ete ouverte a Anvers et au Caire (aux guichets de l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank et de la Societe Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerce), la souscription aux 11,000 actions nouvelles de l'Egyptian Enterprise and Development, dont nous avons parle dans notre Circulaire du 28 fevrier dernier.

La souscription sera close demain soir. Tout indique qu'elle est appelee a un grand succes, justifie, d'ailleurs, par l'excellente situation de la Societe, le beau dividende qu'elle vient de repartir, la hausse constante du titre, le developpement remarquable de ses affaires et les belles perspectives qui s'ouvrent devant elle.

A l'assembles de la Societe des Eaux du du Caire, tenue vendredi, le conseil d'administration a propose de distribuer : 5 francs par action de capital; 8 fr. 25 par action de jouissance; 50 fr. 60 par part de fondateur, et 5 fr. 06 par dixieme de part de fondateur. Ces sommes serant payees a 1'echeance du 1er Avril.

Il ressort du dernier etat comparatif publie par la Brasserie des Pyramides que la vente de biere et de glace en Janvier et Fevrier 1906 s'est elevee a £2378 contre 1646 1/2 pour la periode correspondante de l'annee derniere, soit un surplus de £731 1/2.
Nouvelle hausse sur les cotons en Amerique. Avant-hier, le disponible a gagne non moins de 20 points, le Mai 15 et l'Octobre 9.
D'apres ce qu'on nous cable de Liverpool, le commerce est tres actif, le stock decroit et beaucoup de filateurs sont a court de coton.
D'autre part, des avis de New York portent qu'on s'attend a une nouvelle avance par suite de l'effet exerce par le mauvais temps sur les plantations.
Les arrivages ont ete de 13,000 balles contre 21,000.
Le marche de Liverpool est tres ferme.

Ici, le Mars, qui avait cloture samedi soir a 19 3/4 sans vendeurs, sur les achats du commerce de la s. eculation, l'importance des exportations et les ventes de Liverpool, a ouvert ce matin a 19 15/16 pour atteindre 20 1/16 et cloture a 19 3/4.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.&O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These express steamer's have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig or Saida Zenab.
